children.text: Because when you read with read(*,*) s, it expects the input to be a string of exactly n characters.

children.text: For example, if the input line for s is "UDU", then s will be "UDU". But when the user inputs the strings, perhaps with leading or trailing spaces, but the code expects the entire string to be read. So using list-directed input (read(*, *)) may split on spaces, which is not desired.

children.text:
To avoid this, the code should read the entire line as a single string. So perhaps using formatted input with a format specifier. So for reading s and t, the code can read them using a format of (A), which reads the entire line, but truncated to the length of the variable. So:

read(*,'(A)') s But in Fortran, when you read with '(A)', it reads the entire line, but leading and trailing spaces are included. So if the input line is "UDU " (with trailing space), then s would be "UDU " (including the space).
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
For example, if the user enters more than n characters, it's truncated, less, it's padded with spaces. So the code expects that s and t are provided as contiguous sequences of characters without spaces, each exactly length n.

So in Fortran, to read s and t as exactly n characters each, the code can use a format specifier of (A), and the user must input the correct length. So:

read(*, '(A)')

s

Now, putting all this together. The Fortran code would look like:

program atcoder_AGC033_B
    implicit none
    integer :: h, w, n, sr, sc
    character(len=:), allocatable :: s, t
    logical :: end
    integer :: usafe, dsafe, lsafe, rsafe, i
    character :: c, tc

    ! Read input
    read(*,*) h, w, n, sr, sc
    allocate(character(n) :: s)
    allocate(character(n) :: t)
    read(*,'(A)') s
    read(*,'(A)') t

    end = .false.

    ! Process vertical direction (U/D)
    usafe = 1
    dsafe = h
    do i = n, 1, -1
        c = s(i:i)
        if (c == 'U') then
            usafe = usafe + 1
        else if (c == 'D') then
            dsafe = dsafe - 1
        end if
        if (usafe > dsafe) then
            end = .true. exit
        end if
        if (i > 1) then
            tc = t(i-1:i-1)
            if (tc == 'U') then
                dsafe = min(dsafe + 1, h)
            else if (tc == 'D') then
                usafe = max(usafe - 1, 1)
            end if
        end if
    end do

    ! Process horizontal direction (L/R)
    lsafe = 1
    rsafe = w
    do i = n, 1, -1
        c = s(i:i) if (c == 'L') then
            lsafe = lsafe + 1
        else if (c == 'R') then
            rsafe = rsafe - 1
        end if
        if (lsafe > rsafe) then
            end = .true. exit
        end if
        if (i > 1) then
            tc = t(i-1:i-1)
            if (tc == 'L') then
                rsafe = min(rsafe + 1, w)
            else if (tc == 'R') then
                lsafe = max(lsafe - 1, 1)
            end if
        end if
    end do

    ! Check result
    if ( (sr >= usafe .and. sr <= dsafe) .and. (sc >= lsafe .and. sc <= rsafe) .and. .not.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
end ) then
        print *, "YES"
    else
        print *, "NO"
    end if

    deallocate(s)
    deallocate(t)
end program atcoder_AGC033_B

Putting it all together.

Now, handling the case where end is set during vertical loop. Then, during horizontal loop, it may also set end to true, but since it's already true, the loop may exit early.

But the code in Fortran will proceed to process both loops. For example, after vertical loop sets end to true, horizontal loop will still run. Now, the code in Fortran:

Variables:

integer :: h, w, n, sr, sc
character(len=:), allocatable :: s, t ! Not sure about dynamic length. Alternatively, read as fixed-length.

Wait, but in Fortran, when you read into a character variable, you need to specify the length. So if n is read first, then the code can allocate s and t with length n.

But in Fortran 90 and later, you can use allocatable characters. So:

read(*,*) h, w, n, sr, sc
allocate(character(n) :: s, t)
read(*,*) s
read(*,*) t

But how to read them? Because when you read with read(*,*) s, it expects the input to be a string of exactly n characters. For example, if the input line for s is "UDU", then s will be "UDU".

But when the user inputs the strings, perhaps with leading or trailing spaces, but the code expects the entire string to be read. So using list-directed input (read(*, *)) may split on spaces, which is not desired. For example, if the s is "U D", then the read would read "U" as the first token and "D" as the next, but that's not intended.

To avoid this, the code should read the entire line as a single string. So perhaps using formatted input with a format specifier.

So for reading s and t, the code can read them using a format of (A), which reads the entire line, but truncated to the length of the variable. So:

read(*,'(A)') s

But in Fortran, when you read with '(A)', it reads the entire line, but leading and trailing spaces are included. So if the input line is "UDU " (with trailing space), then s would be "UDU " (including the space). Which may be a problem if the code expects exactly n characters. So perhaps the code should read the s and t as n characters each.

But how to ensure that? For example, if the user enters more than n characters, it's truncated, less, it's padded with spaces.

But according to the original code, s and t are read as next() tokens, which in Java would read until whitespace. So the code expects that s and t are provided as contiguous sequences of characters without spaces, each exactly length n.

So in Fortran, to read s and t as exactly n characters each, the code can use a format specifier of (A), and the user must input the correct length. So:

read(*, '(A)') s
read(*, '(A)') t

But in Fortran, if s is declared as character(n), then reading with (A) will read the entire line, but the variable will take the first n characters. If the line is longer than n, the rest is ignored. If shorter, padded with spaces.

Assuming that the user's input for s and t is exactly n characters each, this will work. Otherwise, it may lead to errors. But according to the problem statement, s and t are of length n, so this is okay.

But in the code, the original Java code uses s and t as strings of length n each. So the Fortran code should read them as such.

Now, putting all this together.

The Fortran code would look like:

program atcoder_AGC033_B
    implicit none
    integer :: h, w, n, sr, sc
    character(len=:), allocatable :: s, t
    logical :: end
    integer :: usafe, dsafe, lsafe, rsafe, i
    character :: c, tc

    ! Read input
    read(*,*) h, w, n, sr, sc
    allocate(character(n) :: s)
    allocate(character(n) :: t)
    read(*,'(A)') s
    read(*,'(A)') t

    end = .false.

    ! Process vertical direction (U/D)
    usafe = 1
    dsafe = h
    do i = n, 1, -1
        c = s(i:i)
        if (c == 'U') then
            usafe = usafe + 1
        else if (c == 'D') then
            dsafe = dsafe - 1
        end if
        if (usafe > dsafe) then
            end = .true.
            exit
        end if
        if (i > 1) then
            tc = t(i-1:i-1)
            if (tc == 'U') then
                dsafe = min(dsafe + 1, h)
            else if (tc == 'D') then
                usafe = max(usafe - 1, 1)
            end if
        end if
    end do

    ! Process horizontal direction (L/R)
    lsafe = 1
    rsafe = w
    do i = n, 1, -1
        c = s(i:i)
        if (c == 'L') then
            lsafe = lsafe + 1
        else if (c == 'R') then
            rsafe = rsafe - 1
        end if
        if (lsafe > rsafe) then
            end = .true.
            exit
        end if
        if (i > 1) then
            tc = t(i-1:i-1)
            if (tc == 'L') then
                rsafe = min(rsafe + 1, w)
            else if (tc == 'R') then
                lsafe = max(lsafe - 1, 1)
            end if
        end if
    end do

    ! Check result
    if ( (sr >= usafe .and. sr <= dsafe) .and. (sc >= lsafe .and. sc <= rsafe) .and. .not. end ) then
        print *, "YES"
    else
        print *, "NO"
    end if

    deallocate(s)
    deallocate(t)
end program atcoder_AGC033_B

But wait, in the horizontal loop, the code is processing s's i-th character again. But in the Java code, the vertical loop processes s's characters for U and D, and the horizontal loop processes s's characters for L and R. So in the Fortran code, the horizontal loop is also processing s(i:i), checking for 'L' and 'R'.

Yes. Because in Java's horizontal loop, the code has:

for (int i = n-1; i >=0; i--) {
    if (s.charAt(i) == 'L') ... else if (s.charAt(i) == 'R') ...

So yes, the horizontal loop is processing the same s string again, but for different characters. So the Fortran code correctly loops over the same s and processes 'L' and 'R' in the horizontal loop.

Another thing to check: in the horizontal loop, the code uses the same t as the vertical loop. Because in Java's code, during the horizontal loop, it uses the same t string, but accesses the same indices. For example, during the horizontal loop's processing, when i is n-1, and i>0, it accesses t's (i-1) character, which is the same as the vertical loop's access. But in Java, the vertical and horizontal loops are separate and process the same t string's characters. So in Fortran's code, the same t is used in both loops.

Yes, that's correct.

Now, possible issues:

- In Fortran, when reading the strings s and t, if the user inputs more than n characters, they get truncated. If less, they are padded with spaces. But according to the problem statement, s and t are exactly n characters each, so the code is correct.

- The variables are declared correctly, with usafe, dsafe, etc., initialized properly.

- The loops run correctly from n downto 1, and the conditions are handled properly.

- The min and max functions in Fortran are used correctly. For example, min(dsafe + 1, h) is equivalent to Math.min in Java.

- The final check includes all conditions.

So this should be the correct translation.
